","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"NEUR2201","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"NEUR2201 - Neuroscience Fundamentals","description":"

This course will address five big questions in modern neuroscience. A new question will be explored each fortnight in lectures, a laboratory class and tutorial. One focus of the course is on the range of disciplines that contribute to the field of neuroscience, and each fortnight’s topic will be taught by academics from two or more disciplines (Anatomy, Pharmacology, Physiology, Psychology, Clinical Neuroscience) using an integrated approach. Students will develop an insight into how problems in neuroscience are investigated, and an appreciation of some current issues.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"29c2a16edbafa050be4672f5f39619e3","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":"Group","value":"Group"},"assessment_name":"Group project Neuroscience in the Media","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"20","description":"

The group project comprises submission of a group Wiki page on a Neuroscience topic of your choice, presentation of a summary of this topic to the class, reflection on teamwork, and participation in critical appraisal of a peer’s Wiki.  The details of the various components are described in detail in the Wiki link on Moodle.

Feedback on your Wiki will be provided by the end of term and you will get immediate feedback from peers and tutors during your presentation.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"69c2e16edbafa050be4672f5f39619c5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"69c2e16edbafa050be4672f5f39619c6","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"69c2e16edbafa050be4672f5f39619c9","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Final exam","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"40","description":"

The final exam is 2 hours long, and consists of a mix of multiple choice questions, and short answer questions (one per topic).

Marks will be incorporated into a final grade.

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"61c2e16edbafa050be4672f5f39619c6","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"61c2e16edbafa050be4672f5f39619c7","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"6dc2e16edbafa050be4672f5f39619c4","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"75c2e16edbafa050be4672f5f39619e0","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Short answer practice & peer marking","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"20","description":"

To give you some experience with the written question format of the final exam and to develop skills in critical analysis and written communication we will have fortnightly short answer assessments that includes a peer-marking component (using a provided marking scheme), monitored by the academic staff.  50% of marks are allocated for your actual answer, and 50% of marks are allocated for your peer assessment. Each of the four short answer assessments are worth 5% each to sum to the 20% final mark. We will have a formative (pratice) activity to help guide this process. 

Peer review enables you to get immediate feedback on short answer writing and on your own answer.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"61c2e16edbafa050be4672f5f39619c6","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"61c2e16edbafa050be4672f5f39619c7","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"6dc2e16edbafa050be4672f5f39619c4","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"b1c2e16edbafa050be4672f5f39619cf","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Ongoing on-line assessment quizzes","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

Each fortnight-long module has a short quiz at the end of the module. These quizzes are presented via an online platform, take about 10-20 minutes to complete. A variety of forms of assessment are used in the quizzes including multiple choice, single word answers, labelling figures and filling gaps in text. Each quiz is summed to give the 20% final mark. These quizzes help you keep up to date on the content.

Immediate feedback is given, providing an indication on your level of study and understanding of the content from lectures, tutes and practical classes in the preceding module.          

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"61c2e16edbafa050be4672f5f39619c6","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"61c2e16edbafa050be4672f5f39619c7","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"6dc2e16edbafa050be4672f5f39619c4","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"bdc2e16edbafa050be4672f5f39619e4","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/NEUR2201.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

Muscle and Motor Control","description":"

This course examines how movement is controlled from brain to skeletal muscle. The major themes are the contribution of the brain and spinal cord to the control of movement, muscle function, motor learning, movement disorders, fatigue and ageing. A series of advanced practical classes will range from experiments with isolated mammalian muscle to human studies with electromyography. The lectures, practicals and tutorials will be complemented by a series of expert seminars which provide insight into current research in the field and reinforce the relationship between integrative neuromotor function, movement physiology and the cellular and molecular physiology underlying muscle and motor control.


For more detailed information, please click on "Course Outline" in box below.

The format will be mix of multiple choice questions and short answer questions. Feedback is provided through a final course grade.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"22fa0a6fdbb59850eb6b147a3a961965","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"66fa0a6fdbb59850eb6b147a3a961986","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"6efa0a6fdbb59850eb6b147a3a961967","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"e2fa0a6fdbb59850eb6b147a3a961962","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"1efa0a6fdbb59850eb6b147a3a961958","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Progress theory and practical quizzes","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

These online quizzes are composed of pre-prac and post-prac quizzes (10%) and progress quizzes (10%).  The pre-prac quizzes are designed to ensure students come to the laboratory prepared. The post-prac quizzes test students’ understanding of the results obtained in the prac class and the ability to put these results into theoretical context.  The progress quizzes occur after each week’s activities and aim to revisit and review course content on a regular basis.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"22fa0a6fdbb59850eb6b147a3a961965","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"66fa0a6fdbb59850eb6b147a3a961986","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"6efa0a6fdbb59850eb6b147a3a961967","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"aafa0a6fdbb59850eb6b147a3a96196a","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"8afa0a6fdbb59850eb6b147a3a96193e","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Solving a research challenge","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"20","description":"

In this assignment students will have to design an evidence based experiment and present mock results in the strict format used in scientific literature. This assignment will be marked with feedback using detailed rubric, with feedback provided on each aspect and with in-text comments.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"22fa0a6fdbb59850eb6b147a3a961965","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"6efa0a6fdbb59850eb6b147a3a961967","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"aafa0a6fdbb59850eb6b147a3a96196a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"e2fa0a6fdbb59850eb6b147a3a961962","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"c2fa0a6fdbb59850eb6b147a3a961943","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Motor control explained (blended learning assignment)","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"20","description":"

In small groups (3-4), students will choose one of the motor control topics discussed during lectures or tutorials, and will produce a short educational video to explain the underlying principles and demonstrate motor control in action. Created blended learning products will be peer marked by other students, thereby providing feedback on the product. Students will also receive marks for contribution to this peer assessment process. The final mark is determined by the course convenors but based on the average peer marks.

This course provides an integrative approach to understanding cellular neuroscience. It begins with an understanding of cell membranes and the mathematical equations that describe the movement of ions. It then builds a repertoire of the key molecules that underlie the processes of signalling in neural cells. These are then combined to understand the behaviour of neural cell signalling and how these may be manipulated experimentally to understand the function. Topic areas include: how electrical signals are generated across cell membranes; the function, properties and structure of ion channels, receptors and transporters; how nerve cells communicate with each other in the brain, including synaptic transmission and receptor-mediated signalling; how alterations in function can lead to disease states; modern experimental techniques in cellular neuroscience; application of molecular biology techniques to manipulate and explore the function of molecules in the nervous system. The course provides an ideal introduction for further studies in neuroscience and pharmacology, and provides a foundation for the understanding of higher physiological systems.


For more detailed information, please click on "Course Outline" in box below.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"000b4a6fdbb59850eb6b147a3a96199f","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"The collaborative assignment","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"25","description":"

The collaborative assignment will require students to work in teams of four students, researching the properties of a gene product. The gene product is an ion channel and there are one or more diseases that are associated with mutations in the gene. Teams will use online databases to identify characteristics of the gene and the ion channel for which it codes. A literature search will be required to identify the function of the channel and how this is altered in the disease state.  The team will produce a scoping report, a summary of normal function and a final report, all of which are submitted online.  The final report must include a statement on the contribution of each team member.  Each member will also provide an individual reflection on how they have worked together as a team. The final report is a review style article aimed at a general scientific audience, providing information on the function of the ion channel and the effect of the mutation on the ion channel to cause the disease state. The assessment will be based on the ability of the team to identify relevant information from appropriate sources and provide proper references for all sources; the team needs to be able to analyse the variety of information collected and communicate this in a manner that demonstrates an integration of the material, not just summarising the individual components. They need to identify the likely molecular mechanism for how the mutation in the ion channel can cause the disease state. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"040b4a6fdbb59850eb6b147a3a96199b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"c40b4a6fdbb59850eb6b147a3a961998","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"73fa4a6fdbb59850eb6b147a3a961942","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Progress exams","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"20","description":"

There will be two progress exams throughout the course, each 40 minutes in duration.  These exams will be comprised of short answer questions, multiple choice and/or short calculations.  The questions will be based on the material covered in the lectures, the concept quizzes from the practical classes and the tutorials.  This will assess your understanding and application of the concepts developed in the course.  The exams will be held at the start of the scheduled practical class sessions.  Please see the course schedule for the specific dates.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"040b4a6fdbb59850eb6b147a3a96199b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"0c0b4a6fdbb59850eb6b147a3a96197c","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"cc0b4a6fdbb59850eb6b147a3a961979","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"bbfa4a6fdbb59850eb6b147a3a961946","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Concept quizzes","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"15","description":"

The ‘concept quizzes’ will assess your understanding and application of the key concepts that are explored in the practical classes.The practical classes are provided to support the lecture material and to practice applying analytical skills to biological problems.  The material covered in the practical classes will be assessed in the progress exams in addition to the ‘concept quizzes’.   The key concepts for each practical class are provided on Moodle. The quiz for each class will be available online via Moodle for a limited time. In most cases it will be possible to complete the quiz at the end of the practical class, however for those classes that take up the entire allocated time, the quiz will need to be completed in your own time. The deadline by which the quizzes need to be completed will be provided on Moodle.

\n

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"0c0b4a6fdbb59850eb6b147a3a96197c","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"cc0b4a6fdbb59850eb6b147a3a961979","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"f3fa4a6fdbb59850eb6b147a3a961918","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"End of session exam","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"40","description":"

The end of session exam will be comprised of short answer questions that will include some mathematical calculations and a UNSW approved calculator will be required.  The short answer questions will be based on the material covered in the lectures and tutorials.  Material covered in the progress exams may be again examined in the final exam.  The lecturer who provided the question will mark the short answers.  Students are advised to use the list of previous exam questions provided to self-evaluate their progress during the course, although questions from year to year may vary as the content of the course is developed.

The course leads students through the study of brain function from a cellular and synaptic level, through to a systems and functional level. Content includes cellular and synaptic neuroscience, and builds to investigate different aspects of sensory systems, and higher order brain processing and brain dysfunction.  Teaching is structured around developing knowledge of brain function from a cellular to systems and functional approaches. Content is delivered by discipline experts, drawn from different research area, with teaching activities encompassing face-to-face lectures, tutorials and practical classes.


Note: Students cannot concurrently enrol in NEUR2201


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"dd65522fdb399850eb6b147a3a9619e1","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"End of Session Exam","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"40","description":"

The end of session exam will be comprised of short answer questions, multiple choice and/or short calculations that may include some simple calculations.  The short answer questions will be based on the material covered in the lectures, tutorials and practical classes.  The exam is comprehensive; material covered in the progress exams may be again examined in the final exam.  Results will be released once graded.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"8d65522fdb399850eb6b147a3a9619bc","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"c965522fdb399850eb6b147a3a9619bf","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"d165522fdb399850eb6b147a3a9619de","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"0165522fdb399850eb6b147a3a9619a7","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Prelab quizzes","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"10","description":"

Prelab quizzes are based on the relevant lecture material and prelab video content and serve to prepare students for the practical class.  Quizzes are available via the online learning management system and are completed in your own time prior to the practical class. Typically these are multiple choice or short answer questions. Students will receive immediate feedback after submitting your answers.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"8d65522fdb399850eb6b147a3a9619bc","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"c965522fdb399850eb6b147a3a9619bf","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"7465522fdb399850eb6b147a3a961999","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Midterm Exam","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"25","description":"

The midterm exam will be comprised of short answer questions, multiple choice and/or short calculations.  The questions will be based on the material covered in the lectures, tutorials and practical classes.  The midterm exam will enable students to assess their level of understanding and application of the concepts developed in the first half of the course. The exam also provides students a chance to prepare for the final exam. Feedback is provided through course grades and model answers released to students following assessment.

               

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"8d65522fdb399850eb6b147a3a9619bc","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"c965522fdb399850eb6b147a3a9619bf","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"bc65522fdb399850eb6b147a3a96199d","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"DIY practical","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"25","description":"

Groups of students will design and complete their own neurophysiology experiment. Prior to undertaking the experiment, students submit a proposal document describing the research question and experimental design.  Students also complete a risk assessment for the experiment.  After completing the experiment students submit a practical report.  Marks are allocated based on the proposal document, risk assessment and practical report.  20% of the total will be a group mark and 5% an individual mark. Multiple practical classes are dedicated to the DIY prac and students are provided with feedback and support throughout the research process.  Specific comments and marks will be provided on the proposal document and practical report.

The course is an introduction to psychophysiology and behavioural neuroscience, i.e. the rigorous empirical study of mind body relations.  It is designed specifically for Neuroscience Honours students.

Multiple choice or short answer questions from the weekly seminars and assigned readings. The exam will be prepared for delivery either in person or online via Moodle.  

 

Assessment will probe an understanding of the topics covered and will be marked by the tutor and / or course coordinator.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"2a50423cdbe6281055a93324f3961955","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"965d7da1db2ce41055a93324f39619e2","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"165d7da1db2ce41055a93324f39619ea","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Group","value":"Group"},"assessment_name":"Group Presentation","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"30","description":"

Students will be required to participate in a single 20-30 minute group presentation carried out in class. 5-10 minutes will be allocated for questions and discussion. Students will be allocated to groups (2-4 students/group, depending on class size) to present a journal article assigned by the course coordinators. This presentation will be prepared using PowerPoint and delivered either via Teams or in person.

 

Students will be marked and receive brief written feedback from the tutorial facilitator/ course coordinator. Marks will be allocated based on the content and clarity of presentation (visual and verbal), as well as capacity to answer questions and engage in discussion. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"2960427cdbe6281055a93324f396194b","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"5e5d7da1db2ce41055a93324f39619e7","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Essay on Neuroscience related topic","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

Students will write a 4 page (double spaced) essay on a contemporary issue in behavioural neuroscience. The exact topic will vary from year to year. Students will be required to summarise and critically evaluate the primary literature and provide references to justify their stance.

 

Students will receive marks based on the structure, content and narrative of the essay, as well how well they use evidence to support any arguments, and their ability to show evidence of critical thinking and insight. Brief written feedback will be provided by the tutor/course coordinator. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"2960427cdbe6281055a93324f396194b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"2a50423cdbe6281055a93324f3961955","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"965d7da1db2ce41055a93324f39619e4","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/NEUR4411.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}
contentlets.description: The course is an introduction to psychophysiology and behavioural neuroscience, i.e. the rigorous empirical study of mind body relations.  It is designed specifically for Neuroscience Honours students.
contentlets.title: Behavioural Perspectives in Neuroscience

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"NEUR4421","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"NEUR4421 - Biomedical Perspectives in Neuroscience","description":"

This course offers workshops on specific current 'hot topic' issues in biomedical neurobiology, where you will be exposed to the latest research.  Hands-on activities will give you real insight into modern neuroscience techniques, their correct implementation and their limitations. It is designed specifically for Neuroscience Honours students.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"003533c2db0fe410fe4b322af49619da","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"3 Minute Thesis Presentation","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"30","description":"

An essential skill for a modern scientist is the ability to communicate research projects and findings to a broad audience. This is particularly important in an academic setting as the research conducted at universities and research institutes is primary funding through public money.  To develop the communication skills of post-graduate research students The University of Queensland created a Three Minute Thesis (3MT®) competition. The competition has been adopted by universities throughout the world.

Students will prepare a 3 minute presentation of their thesis research to date in accordance with the Three Minute Thesis rules. 

Students will receive written feedback from the workshop facilitator, and the course coordinator. Assessment will be marked by the course conveners and SoMS-based Neuroscience Honours committee members.

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"c83533c2db0fe410fe4b322af49619da","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"cc3533c2db0fe410fe4b322af49619dc","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"043573c2db0fe410fe4b322af49619c3","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Online quizzes (40 %)","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"40","description":"

Workshops will be followed by quizzes.  Quiz questions will be based on the material covered in the workshop and will enable students to assess their level of understanding of the material presented in the workshop. Quizzes are available via the online learning management system and typically consist of multiple choice or short answer questions.  Students will receive immediate feedback after submitting their answers.

Number of quizzes: Each NEUR4421 student attends 4 workshops; 2 mandatory workshops and 2 elective workshops. There is one quiz associated with each workshop. Therefore, students will attempt 4 quizzes. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"c43533c2db0fe410fe4b322af49619dc","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"8c3533c2db0fe410fe4b322af49619de","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Group","value":"Group"},"assessment_name":"Student Journal Presentation","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

Students will present, in small groups, a journal article to the class using PowerPoint or equivalent. The presentation will include an explanation of the motivation for the study, a description of the experimental approach, and a critical analysis of the results and the authors conclusions. The PowerPoint will be submitted for assessment.


Students will receive written feedback from the workshop facilitator, the course coordinator, and peers. The feedback will be delivered prior to the second presentation. Journal club assessment will be marked by the course conveners and workshop facilitator (25%). A peer review assessment will contribute 5% of the mark.

Students will engage in an experimental research project, supervised by a member of academic staff.   This research project includes project planning, literature review, experimental work, statistical analyses and oral and written reporting. This course represents part of the total 36 UOC research project that forms the core of Neuroscience Honours.


 


 

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"0f800ed0dbb6d010eb6b147a3a9619db","name":"Independent research - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Thesis","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"80","description":"

The Research Thesis is a written scientific account of the student's independent research conducted during their Honour's year. The Research Thesis should be not more than 10,000 words. The general format of the research report is aligned with the guidelines for the project manuscript assessment item submitted for Honours in the School of Medical Sciences. It should contain an abstract, acknowledgments, brief introduction with aims and hypotheses, materials and methods, results, discussion and references sections. The word limit excludes the abstract, acknowledgements and references sections, as well as supplementary data (if present), tables, figures and legends used in the text. Penalties will apply for an inability to observe the word limit. The abstract should succinctly and accurately summarise the aims and outcomes of the project. The acknowledgments are to be used to indicate how much of the research was performed independently or cooperatively. The brief introduction, aims and hypothesis section should define the problem being examined and place it in the context of published work in the area without being a complete review of the literature. It should identify the limitations of the literature and areas of controversy and give clear and valid aims and hypotheses. The methods should be appropriate and valid for the stated aims and clearly described and fully referenced. The results should reflect the body of laboratory work including sufficient controls and replicates and analysis of data using appropriate statistical tests. Material needed for a complete understanding or evaluation of the work, but which does not fit well in the manuscript format, should be included as supplementary data. Presentation of the results should be clear and logical and should communicated appropriately (using figures and tables as well as text). The discussion should be relevant to the introduction, methods, and results sections, logical in presentation and scientific content, show critical/creative analysis, place the findings of the study in the context of past studies and have suggestions for future studies. Please note that all work which is integral to the manuscript but was not performed by the student (i.e. undertaken by another member of the research group) is to be clearly disclosed in the Methods and/or Results sections of the report, where appropriate. This work may then be referred to in the Discussion and be assessed in the context of the methods and results attained by the student. The referencing style of the project manuscript should align with the requirements of the literature review.


Students receive written feedback from two examiners (neither of whom are their supervisor).

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"4b804ed0dbb6d010eb6b147a3a96197f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"8f800ed0dbb6d010eb6b147a3a9619dc","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"1b804ed0dbb6d010eb6b147a3a96198b","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Lay Summary","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"5","description":"

Students provide a two page lay summary of their research in language suitable for an educated reader outside the field to understand.


The lay summary is marked by the Neuroscience Honours Committee. The marks are communicated to the student.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"87800ed0dbb6d010eb6b147a3a9619dd","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"83804ed0dbb6d010eb6b147a3a961989","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Proposal","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"10","description":"

The Research Proposal should be not more than 5,000 words and should give a detailed account of published scientific literature most directly relevant to the project being undertaken. It should contain a brief introduction that identifies briefly the problem under investigation and background to it, the body of the review and a conclusion relating the body of knowledge to the research aims and objectives. The research plan should be outlined, explaining the rationale for the methods chosen. The proposal should include a timeline of activities and any planned absences. The review should be critical, highlighting limitations of the literature and/or areas of controversy. It should be adequately referenced with recent and appropriate studies and have clear and logical flow. The word count for the literature review excludes non-text elements such as diagrams and tables, which can be used. Penalties will apply for an inability to observe the word limit. The general and referencing style should follow that of a journal relevant to the area of research.


Students receive written feedback in the form of questions to which they will need to write a rejoinder.

\n

Students provide a three page reply to the queries raised by the two examiners of their proposal. Responses can be integrated where the two assessors have overlapping concerns. Every concern must be addressed in a systematic way.

\n

Assessment and feedback on the rejoinder is provided based on a rubric under development. Marks are determined by the assessors of the research proposal and reviewed by the Neuroscience Honours Committee.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"4b804ed0dbb6d010eb6b147a3a96197f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"87800ed0dbb6d010eb6b147a3a9619dc","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"8b804ed0dbb6d010eb6b147a3a961981","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Proposal seminar","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"5","description":"

The seminar is of 10 minutes duration, with an additional 10 minutes for questions. The presentation should largely cover the results of the research project. A clear, concise and appropriate introduction should be provided which identifies the limitations of the literature and areas of controversy. Clear and valid aims and hypotheses should also be stated. The seminar should cover the methods and the rationale for their use. The seminar should have clear and logical flow, good pace (i.e. neither hurried nor laboured) and use good quality visual aids. The student should demonstrate understanding of the questions raised during question time by giving appropriate answers.


Assessment and feedback are based on a rubric aligned with that used for Honours in SOMS. Criteria within the rubric address the following: Background, Hypotheses, Aims, Methods, Presentation Skills and Questions. The seminar will be marked and feedback provided by the supervisor and guest academics and/or research group members.

In either case a final grade is withheld until the final course is completed."}],"credit_points_header":"18 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"NEUR4443 - Neuroscience Research 18 Units of Credit","description":"

Students will engage in an experimental research project, supervised by a member of academic staff.   This research project includes project planning, literature review, experimental work, statistical analyses and oral and written reporting. This course represents part of the total 36 UOC research project that forms the core of Neuroscience Honours.


 


 

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"aa84c218dbb6d010eb6b147a3a96194d","name":"Independent research - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Thesis","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"80","description":"

The Research Thesis is a written scientific account of the student's independent research conducted during their Honour's year. The Research Thesis should be not more than 10,000 words. The general format of the research report is aligned with the guidelines for the project manuscript assessment item submitted for Honours in the School of Medical Sciences. It should contain an abstract, acknowledgments, brief introduction with aims and hypotheses, materials and methods, results, discussion and references sections. The word limit excludes the abstract, acknowledgements and references sections, as well as supplementary data (if present), tables, figures and legends used in the text. Penalties will apply for an inability to observe the word limit. The abstract should succinctly and accurately summarise the aims and outcomes of the project. The acknowledgments are to be used to indicate how much of the research was performed independently or cooperatively. The brief introduction, aims and hypothesis section should define the problem being examined and place it in the context of published work in the area without being a complete review of the literature. It should identify the limitations of the literature and areas of controversy and give clear and valid aims and hypotheses. The methods should be appropriate and valid for the stated aims and clearly described and fully referenced. The results should reflect the body of laboratory work including sufficient controls and replicates and analysis of data using appropriate statistical tests. Material needed for a complete understanding or evaluation of the work, but which does not fit well in the manuscript format, should be included as supplementary data. Presentation of the results should be clear and logical and should communicated appropriately (using figures and tables as well as text). The discussion should be relevant to the introduction, methods, and results sections, logical in presentation and scientific content, show critical/creative analysis, place the findings of the study in the context of past studies and have suggestions for future studies. Please note that all work which is integral to the manuscript but was not performed by the student (i.e. undertaken by another member of the research group) is to be clearly disclosed in the Methods and/or Results sections of the report, where appropriate. This work may then be referred to in the Discussion and be assessed in the context of the methods and results attained by the student. The referencing style of the project manuscript should align with the requirements of the literature review.


Students receive written feedback from two examiners (neither of whom are their supervisor).

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"6684c218dbb6d010eb6b147a3a96194f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"6e84c218dbb6d010eb6b147a3a96194f","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"76840618dbb6d010eb6b147a3a961985","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Proposal","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"10","description":"

The Research Proposal should be not more than 5,000 words and should give a detailed account of published scientific literature most directly relevant to the project being undertaken. It should contain a brief introduction that identifies briefly the problem under investigation and background to it, the body of the review and a conclusion relating the body of knowledge to the research aims and objectives. The research plan should be outlined, explaining the rationale for the methods chosen. The proposal should include a timeline of activities and any planned absences. The review should be critical, highlighting limitations of the literature and/or areas of controversy. It should be adequately referenced with recent and appropriate studies and have clear and logical flow. The word count for the literature review excludes non-text elements such as diagrams and tables, which can be used. Penalties will apply for an inability to observe the word limit. The general and referencing style should follow that of a journal relevant to the area of research.


Students receive written feedback in the form of questions to which they will need to write a rejoinder.

\n

Students provide a three page reply to the queries raised by the two examiners of their proposal. Responses can be integrated where the two assessors have overlapping concerns. Every concern must be addressed in a systematic way.

\n

Assessment and feedback on the rejoinder is provided based on a rubric under development. Marks are determined by the assessors of the research proposal and reviewed by the Neuroscience Honours Committee.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"6a84c218dbb6d010eb6b147a3a96194e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"6e84c218dbb6d010eb6b147a3a96194f","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"be840618dbb6d010eb6b147a3a961988","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Proposal seminar","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"5","description":"

The seminar is of 10 minutes duration, with an additional 10 minutes for questions. The presentation should largely cover the results of the research project. A clear, concise and appropriate introduction should be provided which identifies the limitations of the literature and areas of controversy. Clear and valid aims and hypotheses should also be stated. The seminar should cover the methods and the rationale for their use. The seminar should have clear and logical flow, good pace (i.e. neither hurried nor laboured) and use good quality visual aids. The student should demonstrate understanding of the questions raised during question time by giving appropriate answers.


Assessment and feedback are based on a rubric aligned with that used for Honours in SOMS. Criteria within the rubric address the following: Background, Hypotheses, Aims, Methods, Presentation Skills and Questions. The seminar will be marked and feedback provided by the supervisor and guest academics and/or research group members.
